_ui_color_palette.title: @:work._ui_color_palette.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_ui_color_palette.shortDescription: Accessible color palettes with consistent lightness with Figma
_ui_color_palette.description: Figma is an UX tool, using diagrams to build user experiences, interfaces, prototypes, illustrations, etc. The tool can be extended with a plugin system. Figma tends to be the leader of UX tools market because of its inclusive and powerful business model. So, Figma is still the most exciting ux tool. By reading this article (Accessible Palette: stop using HSL for color systems), I noticed there is not any plugin on Figma to help build accessible color systems for UI. The opportunity is to develop a tool to create, edit and deploy color palettes.

misc.objectives: Creating UI color palettes with consistent lightness and contrast, Updating and deploying colors with ease to the team library
misc.roles: Developing the plugins on Figma/Penpot (React), Defining the long-term strategy, Planning and scheduling tasks/improvements/requests, Handling user interactions (support/interview/feedback)

challenge.title: Make UI color palettes with the LCH color model
challenge.paragraph-1: The plugin uses the LCH (Lightness-Chroma-Hue) model to generate colors according to the chosen lightness scale. The model LCH is relevant to make colors compliant with the WCAG standards.
challenge.paragraph-2: It works like the HSL (Hue-Saturation-Lightness) color model. The HSL is simple to use to build a color system, because the lightness can just be changed to create variants. The LCH too, but the Chroma, and the Hue are automatically adjusted to keep the colors within the sRGB gamut.

part-1.title: Create the palette from scratch (or with a bit of help)
part-1.paragraph-1: Select the colors you want to spread into shades directly from your document's canvas.
part-1.paragraph-2: Let you guide by the existing pre-configured stops (Material Design, Atlassianâ€¦) or make it your own way.
part-1.paragraph-3: Every shade from the starting colors are gathered within a calibrated palette compliant with WCAG guidelines.

part-2.title: Control the palette with WYSIWYG
part-2.paragraph-1: Slide the stops to change the lightness of every color, and keep a palette with consistent contrasts.
part-2.paragraph-2: Rename, add, remove, change, reorder each colorâ€¦ Keep a full control of the color palette.
part-2.paragraph-3: WCAGÂ 2.2 scores help you build the most respectful palette for accessibility.

part-3.title: Deploy and spread the color standard
part-3.paragraph-1: Add with a single click every color of the palette to the document local styles.
part-3.paragraph-2: Publish the local styles and spread standardized color to your team.
part-3.paragraph-3: Export the palette to a JSON document or CSS Custom Properties.

takeaway-1.description: If you want to test the plugin, you can run it on your Figma account from the plugin page.
takeaway-1.alt: External link to the plugin page on Figma Community

takeaway-2.description: UI Color Palette is an open-source project. You can take a glance at the source code on Github.
takeaway-2.alt: External link to the plugin repository on Github

_jeprendsquoi.title: @:work._jeprendsquoi.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_jeprendsquoi.description: I often go at the market, to buy some fresh and local food. For decades, my parents taught me consume local food is the best way to feed, because the local economy is stimulated and the carbon footprint is lower. So, avoiding supermarket and co. is a leitmotiv. However, the local market reveals its own limits because of some absurdities: find some cherries in winter (17â‚¬ a kilogram), some tomatoes or melons on novemberâ€¦ The bitter conclusion is simple: strict seasonality is not in the minds of people.
_jeprendsquoi.illustration: jeprendsquoi illustration with a big smartphone

misc.objectives: Checking a product's seasonality (fruits and vegetable), Encouraging people to contribute to the products' seasonality database
misc.roles: Building and maintaining the database, Creating a brand: jeprendsquoi (the daily helper), Designing a mobile companion to find the right information insitu (supermarket & market), Developing a mobile app with a no-code solution

challenge.title: The problem of non-seasonal food
challenge.paragraph-1: A non-seasonal fruit or vegetable comes from:
challenge.paragraph-2: Abroad, the carbon footprint is high because of the transportation: by boat or plane. And yet, cultivate inside a greenhouse has a more expensive carbon footprint. Indeed, a greenhouse keeps a non-stop heat to simulate the season temperature, and make the cultivation grow. That is why we can see some tomatoes on november, they grow in a greenhouse in Brittany.
challenge.point-1: Abroad, in a country where the cultivation is seasonal or locally unavailable.

part-1.title: A first prototype to solve the problem
part-1.paragraph-1: There are a couple of tools to make some quick database. No-code is an interesting philosophy to build and test quickly something. Airtable has been chosen because its databases can use different visual representations. The grid was the most relevant view to retrieve a vegetable or a fruit and consult its data.
part-1.paragraph-2: The limitation of this representation is the device context. Indeed, the main use case takes place outside, at the market or the supermarket. People are not used to bring their laptop to the supermarket. So, this solution is not viable for a real usage on the ground.
part-1.paragraph-3: Nevertheless, people might take their smartphone! And Notion can be consulted with the native app or via a shared URL. The access point is a bit risky because people might loose the shared URL or their Notion account. So, make a mobile app should be safer.
part-1.caption-1: The grid representation is clear enough to help user to retrieve the product he is looking for. Besides, Airtable provides a discrete search feature to help a bit more. The fruits and vegetables grid views have been divided into two databases in the first instance. Consult the {linkOne} and {linkTwo} databases.
part-1.caption-2: Notion has merged the two Airtable databases into one. Notion operates in the same way and the reason of this migration is simple: Notion is my all-in-one digital workplace. {linkThree}.

part-2.title: Make the data alive and retrievable
part-2.paragraph-1: The data are ready on Notion and can be represented on a mobile app as an interactive list with some additional features: filter, search, expand, share, and contribute. The app has been built with {linkFour}, a no-code mobile app builder, that gathers API calls and Figma templates.
part-2.paragraph-2: The brand has been created and developed around a simple question: What do I take? A question we ask at the supermarket. The purpose is to help people make environmentally friendly choices.
part-2.caption-1: The list of fruits and vegetables is displayed as the main section. The list can be filtered by season.
part-2.caption-2: The search feature allows user to find a specific product
part-2.caption-3: The detailed page gives user the months of consumption and some additional information
part-2.caption-4: Every user can contribute to the list, just by filling the form. A moderation step is required before publishing.
part-2.caption-5: The templates are edited on Figma. Those pages are composed with placeholders, that will be replaced and duplicated thanks to API calls.
part-2.caption-6: The brand has been created and developed around a simple question: What do I take? A question we ask at the supermarket. The purpose is to help people make environmentally friendly choices.
part-2.caption-7: This looping animation is the mobile app loader when the page is not loaded yet.
part-2.caption-8: On the splash screen, the logotype fades in to introduce the app.

info.description: Yuka was a great inspiration at developing the brand, the voice and the ton.
info.alt: External link to the Yuka homepage

_jean_bobby_radio.title: @:work._jean_bobby_radio.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_jean_bobby_radio.shortDescription: iObeya internal and participatory web radio
_jean_bobby_radio.description: Before the COVID-19 pandemic, with my teammate in the UX team, we were used to listen to our Spotify collaborative playlist. A batch of various masterpieces from different personalities. There are some 90's hits: Trip Hop, Alternative rock, Houseâ€¦ Some 80's hits: Goth, New Waveâ€¦ Around 500 tracks we listened to everyday. And yet, a virus has come, and the remote work was the new order. We were distributed. The problem is we cannot use Spotify as a web radio, in order to listen together to our music and react on it. Make our own web radio allows us to retrieve this office atmosphere: Jean-Bobby Radio.

misc.objectives: Listening together to our Spotify collaborative playlist, Retrieving the office atmosphere
misc.roles: Defining the web radio back-end architecture, Creating a graphic universe around our company's mascot, Designing a simple web player and declining the universe through it, Developing and maintaining the web player

part-1.title: Let's start the broadcasting system
part-1.paragraph-1: Build a web radio from scratch is not as easy as expected. The challenge was interesting because a web radio is a complex system where each component is connected to broadcast audio to whom wants to listen to. To explain a bit, the audio is played from a classic computer, then it is encoded and sent to a broadcasting server, and finally, the audio can be played from a player.
part-1.caption-1: The web radio system has been designed thanks to a couple of open-source and free solutions as {linkTwo} or {linkThree}

info.description: This article explains the detailed flow for the most curious (in french)

part-2.title: Bring the motion design at the front-stage
part-2.paragraph-1: The web player gathers few actions: Play/Pause, Volume, Now playing information and notifications, the collaborative playlist and the sound folder link, some information about the project and a feedback zone. The middle of the stage is the most important part of the player: the looping animation.
part-2.caption-1: Around the edge are the player's controls, to get more space at the middle of the stage: Jean-Bobby All Around the World.

part-3.title: Our mascot, All Around the World
part-3.paragraph-1: Jean-Bobby is our company's mascot. We are used to get him during our trips or events. He has become a running gag because a lot a people liked to take him on holidays. Jean-Bobby has seen the beauty of our world while being the heart of iObeya (ex-KAP IT).
part-3.paragraph-2: This animated loop is a tribute to this period. The best pictures have been a great inspiration and have been compiled into one short animation.
part-3.caption-1: This animation has been a great opportunity at using {linkOne} to generate a web-compliant animation. From an Adobe After Effects composition to an animated SVG.

takeaway-1.description: The radio can be played on demand

takeaway-2.description: Jean-Bobby Radio is an open-source project. You can take a glance at the source code on Github.

_iobeya_mobile_ds.title: @:work._iobeya_mobile_ds.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_iobeya_mobile_ds.shortDescription: iObeya mobile application cross-libs design system
_iobeya_mobile_ds.description: The iObeya mobile application extends productivity and operational excellence through a project management system at the fingertips. It was a new opportunity of bootstrapping a new design system model from scratch, enhancing design and tech dependencies. iObeya web application is a monolith, and we were going to divide it into micro-frontends and API-driven developments.

misc.objectives: Standardizing iObeya mobile app components and patterns
misc.roles: Bootstrapping and building interconnected UI blocks, Sharing components/patterns/templates with the design and development team

challenge.title: What is the challenge?
challenge.paragraph-1: In 2019, we thought about how to deploy design at scale. The iObeya mobile application was a great opportunity to start a design system from scratch. Indeed, we have just only turned a little part of the web application monolithic GUI into a design system.
challenge.paragraph-2: The choice of making native apps brought us at reading the {linkOne} and the {linkTwo}. I was in charge of designing reusable UI components, fully compliant with iOS and Android paradigms. We made this decision to keep a same look & feel and to reduce the learning curve when using the application daily.

part-1.title: Why should we make an application?
part-1.paragraph-1: iObeya is a solution for project management via a specific object named Card. The Card aggregates data like a title, a date, an ownerâ€¦ The mobility was a business opportunity to extend the usage of the Cards. The application is a companion to support project and performance management outside rituals and routines. You can learn more about the birth of the project by reading the {linkThree} on his portfolio because he led the initiative.

part-2.title: Atomic design as a philosophy
part-2.paragraph-1: A system consists of interconnecting components each others, in order to design a hierarchy. Atomic design is directly based on organic life: atoms make molecules, molecules make organismsâ€¦
part-2.paragraph-2: The atoms have been defined with the brand team because they own the iObeya Graphical Guidelines. It gathers brand and UI colors, typography, spacing, shadowsâ€¦ These elements are used as parameters to override iOS and Android native components.
part-2.paragraph-3: Sketch is our diagraming software and one feature was really relevant to build an atomic design system: the external components library.
part-2.paragraph-4: Each part of the UI is a reusable component. Building the UI is like playing lego: small parts are stuck together to make bigger parts, and they are stuck each other to make views. In this way, we keep consistency and make a change is easier.
part-2.paragraph-5: Every part was classified and structured in order to deploy them on our versionning system. So, the file is synchronized and can be linked with Sketch to be used as an external library.
part-2.caption-1: Colors adapted for an UI usage and provided by the brand team
part-2.caption-2: Text styles adapted for an UI usage and provided by the brand team
part-2.caption-3: The iOS and Android patterns come from external libraries embed in Sketch. The Master Design System is internally managed by the design team.
part-2.caption-4: Exploded view of the cards list view. It is composed of the overrided iOS navigation bar and a cards list container. Those patterns are subdivided into components which inherit parameters from the iObeya Master Design System.
part-2.caption-5: Big pictures of every component, pattern and template, ready for making every view with ease.

part-3.title: Build the views, to draw the flows
part-3.paragraph-1: By merging data with the templates (provided by the design system), the views emerge with meaning. The time we spent to build a design system was compensated by the quick specs we wrote.
part-3.caption-1: List of Cards where I am assigned
part-3.caption-2: List of notifications (assignment and reminder) to follow my activity
part-3.caption-3: Card editï¼Title, location, status, date, assignment can be changed.
part-3.caption-4: List of Rooms I can access, to change the Card location

_awesome_ipsums.title: @:work._awesome_ipsums.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_awesome_ipsums.shortDescription: Design teamâ€™s own Lorem Ipsums from a simple Google Spreadsheet with Sketch
_awesome_ipsums.description: Sketch is an UX tool, using diagrams to build user experiences, interfaces, prototypes, and illustrationsâ€¦ The tool can be extended with a plugin system where the purpose is to add additional features, or script actions. The idea of making a more fun Lorem Ipsum tool was a great opportunity to make a Sketch Plugin and understand how it works.

misc.objectives: Allowing the design team to use custom lorem ipsums as fake content, Making the fake content collaborative
misc.roles: Developing the scripts to create/update/sync. the custom lorem ipsums

part-1.title: Welcome to the world of collaborative content
part-1.paragraph-1: Lorem ipsumÂ is often used to simulate content into a designed web page. Nevertheless, there may be some issues:
part-1.paragraph-2: Lorem ipsumÂ could be fun, relevant, and fully personalized. A design team can create, collect and reuse his own fake content. How to get this team involved in collecting content?Â An online spreadsheet, because it is easy to maintain and always up-to-date.
part-1.paragraph-3: Google Spreadsheet is simple to use and collaborative. It can act as a micro-database for micro-projects.
part-1.point-1: It does not make any sense.
part-1.point-2: It is quite boring and repetitive.
part-1.caption-1: It is possible to create a new text or update one by filling it with a random value from the spreadsheet

part-2.title: How does it work?
part-2.paragraph-1: The workflow is quite simple: Synchronizing the spreadsheet model to Sketch.
part-2.paragraph-2: Then, creating a text from a random content of the spreadsheet. The text is displayed at the center of the current view.
part-2.paragraph-3: Lastly, a text content can be updated with another random content.

takeaway-1.description: If you want to test the plugin, you can download the archive file from the project repository (double-click on the plugin file to install it).
takeaway-1.alt: External link to download the plugin

_iobeya_whiteboard.title: @:work._iobeya_whiteboard.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_iobeya_whiteboard.shortDescription: Go-to-SaaS solution to enhance iObeya virality and deployment
_iobeya_whiteboard.description: The Whiteboarding session is a lite version of iObeya. Its purpose is to ease the deployment through a company by providing a simple meeting framework, reinforcing the collaboration and introducing the solution. This feature was an opportunity to revamp the UI, follow a design philosophy, involve the team, and make user tests.

misc.objectives: Easing the solution deployment, Go-to-SaaS, Reinforcing the position of iObeya on Innovation & Creativity
misc.roles: Facilitating workshops by using the design thinking philosophy, Designing the vision, Revamping the UI, Writing the user stories

challenge.title: What is the problem?
challenge.paragraph-1: iObeya is a structured and strict software. The model is a room = a declared team = a project. This model has some limitations:
challenge.paragraph-2: The platform is fully customizable but the users must be declared and allocated by hand. Besides, the license limits the number of users in a room.
challenge.paragraph-3: The strict and heavy users management is a big pain, so open the platform to any user is our main assumption.
challenge.point-1: Hard to be deployed through a large company (> 50.000 employees.)
challenge.point-2: Heavy workflow between the requester and the IT service.

part-1.title: Defining several low-fi flows to make stakeholders aligned
part-1.paragraph-1: We needed to validate our assumptions by drafting a first version. First, making stakeholders aligned was a requirement. We started with some business and user outcomes. The main challenge was to open a little bit more the application to external users (a step towards a SaaS solution).
part-1.paragraph-2: We planned 3 stories on the same session: the facilitator, the declared and the external participants. First, we did a storymap to draw the three detailed userflows and prioritize their features. This activity involved the PM, UX, and DEV part.
part-1.paragraph-3: The team involvement was a rewarding experience because some of their ideas have unlocked some uncomfortable situation. As a designer, we must facilitate creative meetings and enable people's capabilities.
part-1.caption-1: The Lean UX is a canvas that gathers business/user outcomes, and the solution to respond to the opportunity.
part-1.caption-2: The userflow is full of comments because every person in the team was involved and encouraged to give feedback. A strong solution is built by a succession of reviews.

part-2.title: An opportunity to think different
part-2.paragraph-1: Make a SaaS solution was a business opportunity to catch more users and get the app more viral. We planned to revamp the UI because making a clear separation between a classic board and a whiteboard may be necessary (e.g. Figma and Figjam).
part-2.paragraph-2: The classic board presents a heavy and dark header, a lot of tools and utilities. A whiteboard has a lighter aspect, to introduce a lite version of the application. The result of this UI revamping is an entire whiteboarding session, animated by 3 users, Pierre (the facilitator), Paul (the participant) and Jacqueline (the external participant). This concept was a nice opportunity of using the emotional design philosophy.
part-2.paragraph-3: Several prototypes have been created to get the stakeholders' approval. Conclusion, our assumptions have been validated after showing the entire session. The stakeholders thought their problem should be resolved with the whiteboarding session.
part-2.caption-3: This cartography details the interaction between the three users during the whiteboard session

info-2.alt: External link to the Paul's prototype

info-3.alt: External link to the Jacqueline's prototype

part-3.title: Technical feasibility enters the field
part-3.paragraph-1: The green light is turned on, so we could go deeper in the detailed specs. First, a technical exploration was required because the UI revamping implied front-end changes. Indeed, the application is built with modules and the whiteboarding session is one of them. Nevertheless, a lot of discussions brought us to roll overâ€¦ In order to deliver quickly the feature, we made some concessions: the lite version of the interface was postponed. Nevertheless, we got to add some soft touches of illustration and animation, to introduce the emotional design.
part-3.paragraph-2: Despite the roll back, the solution responded to the companies' problem: do an activity with any users and outside a room.
part-3.caption-1: The speedy board is the whiteboarding session metaphor
part-3.caption-2: A purged whiteboarding session brings the user to a sad wrinkled paper 404 page
part-3.caption-3: This animation makes a transition between contexts while onboarding the end-user

success.title-1: A pain reliever for large meetings and events
success.paragraph-1: The whiteboarding session including team members, guests, stakeholders, suppliers allows to accelerate decision-making and enable collective intelligence.
success.paragraph-2: Miro is a relevant solution to enable people by doing whiteboarding sessions, and yet, it cannot be fully integrated with a large enterpriseâ€™s standards and processes. This is the reason several large enterprise have deployed iObeya because it can do both.

_axeptio_gusto.title: @:work._axeptio_gusto.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_axeptio_gusto.shortDescription: Design system harmonization for Axeptio products
_axeptio_gusto.description: This project harmonized design language across Axeptio's consent management platform. I analyzed the existing ecosystem, created missing components, bridged the gap between design and development teams, and established consistent workflows. The initiative successfully created a single source of truth and improved cross-departmental collaboration.

misc.objectives: Harmonizing design language across products, Establishing a reliable design workflow, Bridging the gap between design and development
misc.roles: Analyzing the current design ecosystem, Creating components and documentation, Educating designers on contribution, Facilitating communication between teams

challenge.title: What's Axeptio?
challenge.paragraph-1: Axeptio is a company providing a consent management platform for various businesses from small blogs to large online newspaper platforms. Their one-stop platform manages multiple products including user cookie consent, terms of use, and subscriptions. They also maintain a web extension that can handle consent on the user's behalf.
challenge.paragraph-2: My task was to evaluate how design language was implemented across Axeptio's products and marketing assets, propose a long-term plan, and schedule specific actions.

part-1.title: The products in between world
part-1.paragraph-1: Axeptio is a medium business and is composed of 6 developers in Montpellier and 3 designers in Paris.
part-1.paragraph-2: The first tack was to examined each department's environment (design, development, branding), focusing on their tools, sources of truth, and change management processes. The comprehensive analysis revealed several key issues.
part-1.paragraph-3: The platform contained a mixture of legacy and current design languages named Gusto, creating visual inconsistency.
part-1.paragraph-4: The development team had more mature processes and quality standards than the design team, creating a significant gap in delivery expectations. For example, integrated components were available for developers but not for designers. A report was produced to compare the environments according to specific criteria.
part-1.paragraph-5: My mission evolved to focus on improving design workflows, educating designers on contribution practices, and creating missing components. "Complete" was a pilot project I took charge of.
part-1.caption-1: The left part reflects the new design language from the Axeptioâ€™s brand, whereas the right part reflects the previous one.
part-1.caption-2: Due to privacy restrictions, the report cannot be shared. Here is an extract to demonstrate how the audit was conducted.
part-1.caption-3: The Epics are proposals that have been validated by the teams. The main focus was to complete the missing resources on the designers' end.

part-2.title: A place for transparency
part-2.paragraph-1: During the building of this pilot, knowledge management was crucial to minimize the risk of future misadoption.
part-2.paragraph-2: We established specific communication channels to facilitate team interaction, gather and resolve issues, and report decisions and important events. Additionally, we created a page within the company's wiki to support the same purpose in a more structured way. While the channels have provided responsiveness since the pilot began, the wiki page serves as documentation, designed to place the right information where it belongs.
part-2.paragraph-3: This page is also a place for the components inventory and tracking their progress. The main purpose is to sort components by criticality, helping me organize each batch (1-week delivery). The second purpose is to review future batches according to the needs of my consumers.
part-2.paragraph-5: This documentation enables efficient triage, allowing us to prioritize components based on:
part-2.caption-1: The decisions, meetings, updates, and conventions are documented on this page, allowing teams to review the project's history.
part-2.caption-2: The components are sorted and arranged into a kanban view to track progress efficiently. Other views serve different purposes, such as filtering critical components that will be addressed.
part-2.caption-3: The documentation provides concise information about each component's status and location, with additional details available below
part-2.caption-4: This comparison illustrates the gap between components available in Figma and those that have been integrated.

part-3.title: Communication is the key
part-3.paragraph-1: Clear communication channels proved essential to the project's success. I facilitated dedicated meetings to establish design conventions around spacing and sizing systems, positioned the implemented components as the definitive source of truth, and implemented best practices.
part-3.paragraph-2: Developers were kept informed of design decisions, providing the appropriate level of involvement without overwhelming them. Weekly review sessions collected designer feedback for ongoing refinements, while regular change summaries maintained alignment across teams.
part-3.caption-1: Example of a decision followed by a guide, created to maintain a history of the decisions we have made.

part-4.title: Getting departments working closer
part-4.paragraph-1: Bridging interdepartmental gaps became a core focus of the initiative. We primarily targeted improving workflows between the remote design and development teams. Education became a priority to foster mutual empathy and establish shared quality standards. Delivering missing components significantly reduced friction, enabling faster and more efficient work across the organization.
part-4.caption-1: Since the library has been established, component insertions have increased.

part-5.title: A traced path to legacy
part-5.paragraph-1: I was focused on executing the pilot and the long-term strategy. As a design system is an organization, the main point is team member alignment and shared knowledge.
part-5.paragraph-2: This pilot has a short timeline, but a 12-month roadmap set the rhythm for potential actions:
part-5.paragraph-3: I served in a governance role, working closely with the Head of Design to plan and schedule actions. The designersâ€”my primary usersâ€”provided positive feedback, as did the developers whom I supported in integrating and reusing existing components.
part-5.paragraph-4: While considerable work remains, we now have a clearly defined path forward.
part-5.caption-1: The 12-month plan is divided into quarters.

part-5.point-3: Connect environments (React components and Figma components)ãƒ»3 months
part-5.point-4: Switch progressively from legacy to the current design systemãƒ»3 months

_iobeya_creativity.title: @:work._iobeya_creativity.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_iobeya_creativity.shortDescription: Go-to-Creativity: iObeya Brainstorming and Voting session
_iobeya_creativity.description: The Brainstorming and Voting features in iObeya are a uniquely creative combination. They are designed to encourage open dialogue and stimulate innovation. The tone these features bring is distinctive within the iObeya spectrum, where fun and efficiency intersect.

misc.objectives: Enabling collective intelligence, Facilitating creative sessions
misc.roles: Designing the flows for participants and facilitators, Enhancing the immersion of creative meetings with illustrations and animations, Promoting mobility and virality, Overseeing the delivery process

challenge.title: What is the challenge?
challenge.paragraph-1: Serious games serve as a powerful tool for harnessing collective intelligence, solving problems, and defining actions. These games are accessible and easy to play. iObeya is utilized as a presentation tool, with guided meetings, but it falls short in managing creative animations and activities.
challenge.paragraph-2: The challenge lies in efficiently enabling collective intelligence.

part-1.title: Divergence-Convergence as a tool to enable collective intelligence
part-1.paragraph-1: Facilitators use brainstorming to stimulate creativity and voting to achieve results. Brainstorming allows individuals to jot down and share their ideas, while voting aids in selecting the most suitable one. This combination stems from the Double Diamonds model, where the essence lies in the Divergence-Convergence process.

part-2.title: Diverging through Brainstorming
part-2.paragraph-1: To understand the overall process, let's consider a team retrospective as an example. In this situation, team members provide structured feedback. The goal is to identify the most significant issues to address and then establish action plans by the end of the activity.
part-2.paragraph-2: The facilitator sets up the brainstorming session for 10 minutes. After starting the session, both the facilitator and participants enter the brainstorming mode. A brief tutorial is provided to help participants prepare for sharing their ideas.
part-2.paragraph-3: The facilitator grants each participant access to the session. Participants may use the QR code to access the session on their mobile devices.
part-2.paragraph-4: The facilitator concludes the session when the allotted time has elapsed. Each participant is then thanked and involved in the reconciliation phase.
part-2.paragraph-5: The results are collected based on the set of notes configured by the facilitator.
part-2.caption-1: The Actions for Retrospectives board is waiting for receiving team membersâ€™ feedback!
part-2.caption-3: A participant (using a desktop) watching the tutorialâ€¦
part-2.caption-4: A participant (using a mobile) watching the tutorialâ€¦
part-2.caption-5: The facilitatorâ€™s screen, enhancing the remaining time and the ideas submittedâ€¦
part-2.caption-6: A participant (using a desktop) writing feedback according to the legend configured by the facilitatorâ€¦
part-2.caption-7: A participant (using a mobile) writing feedback according to the legend configured by the facilitatorâ€¦
part-2.caption-8: A participant or the facilitator (using a desktop) being graciously thankedâ€¦
part-2.caption-9: A participant (using a mobile) being graciously thankedâ€¦

part-3.title: Convergence through Voting
part-3.paragraph-1: The next step is to select the most relevant ideas based on their priority level. Voting allows team members to converge without getting caught up in endless discussions. The principle is straightforward: allocate tokens to the most relevant ideas or feedback.
part-3.paragraph-2: The facilitator sets up the voting session to last for 10 minutes and assigns a certain number of tokens to each participant. After the session is launched, both the facilitator and participants enter voting mode. This mode is further clarified with a brief animation.
part-3.paragraph-3: When the session time is up, the facilitator concludes it. Each participant is then thanked and invited to the board for the synthesis phase.
part-3.paragraph-4: The results are presented alongside their scores.
part-3.paragraph-5: The activity is nearly complete. After gathering the most "liked" ideas and feedback, participants will record actions and assign an owner for each one.
part-3.caption-2: A participant (using a desktop) watching the tutorialâ€¦
part-3.caption-3: A participant (using a mobile) watching the tutorialâ€¦
part-3.caption-4: The facilitatorâ€™s screen, enhancing the remaining timeâ€¦
part-3.caption-5: A participant (using a desktop) allocating tokens to the batch of selected feedbackâ€¦
part-3.caption-6: A participant (using a mobile) allocating tokens to the batch of selected feedbackâ€¦
part-3.caption-7: A participant or the facilitator (using a desktop) being graciously thankedâ€¦
part-3.caption-8: A participant (using a mobile) being graciously thankedâ€¦

part-4.title: An opportunity to enable Emotional Design
part-4.paragraph-1: To facilitate collective intelligence and enhance creativity, we hypothesize that employing animation and illustrations in the user interface can guide participants toward a certain mindset.
part-4.paragraph-2: Firstly, users need to understand how to participate, for example, through interactions. Both modes include an animated tutorial, as participants may not know how to use iObeya. We presume that this approach could more readily capture users' attention.
part-4.paragraph-3: On the other hand, both of the modes enhance an infinte pattern animation composed by moving particles. It may increase participants attention and it reinforces the identity of each of the modes.
part-4.paragraph-4: Finally, those modes are mainly and simply FUN: the global tone has been designed to bridge fun and efficience.
part-4.caption-1: How to participate in a brainstorming session
part-4.caption-2: How to participate in a voting session

success.title: Go furtherâ€¦
success.paragraph-1: Compared to our competitors (Klaxoon and Mural), iObeya could benefit from several improvements:
success.point-1: Allow external participants to access modes (the whiteboarding session is one possible solution).
success.point-2: Encourage idea generation (through drawings, pictures, rounds, etc.).
success.point-3: Maintain awareness of the activity context.
success.point-4: Facilitate smoother interactions between the facilitator and participants.
